existing_events.early:
- Henry Valentine Miller was born in New York City on December 26, 1891.
- He lived at 450 East 85th Street in Manhattan during his early years.
- His family moved to Williamsburg, Brooklyn when he was around nine years old, and later to Bushwick.
- Miller attended Eastern District High School in Williamsburg.
- He briefly studied at the City College of New York.
- Miller became active with the Socialist Party of America.
- He admired Hubert Harrison.
existing_events.personal:
- Miller married Beatrice Sylvas Wickens in 1917 and divorced her in 1923. They had a daughter, Barbara.
- Miller met June Mansfield around 1924 and they married on June 1, 1924.
- Miller lived with Kronski at some point between 1926-1927.
- Miller moved to Paris in 1930. He spent several months there with June in 1938. During his ten-year stay in Paris, Miller became fluent in French.
- Miller returned to New York in 1940 and moved to California in 1942, initially residing just outside Hollywood in Beverly Glen before settling in Big Sur in 1944.
- Miller married Janina Martha Lepska in 1944 and had two children with her. They divorced in 1952.
- Miller married Eve McClure in 1953 but they divorced in 1960.
- Miller married Hiroko Tokuda in 1967 but they divorced in 1977.
existing_events.career:
- Miller quit Western Union to dedicate himself to writing in 1924.
- He was supported financially by Roland Freedman who paid June Mansfield to write a novel, pretending it was her work and reviewing Miller's writing weekly.
- Miller moved to Paris unaccompanied in 1930.
- He was employed as a proofreader for the Chicago Tribune Paris edition in 1931 thanks to Alfred Perlès.
- This period marked a creative time for Miller, and he began building a network of authors around Villa Seurat.
- Lawrence Durrell became a lifelong friend.
- Anaïs Nin and Hugh Guiler financially supported Miller between 1931-1934, covering his living expenses including rent at 18 Villa Seurat.
- Nin became his lover and financed the first printing of Tropic of Cancer in 1934 with money from Otto Rank.
existing_events.legacy:
- Miller was nominated for the Nobel Prize in Literature by University of Copenhagen professor Allan Philip in 1973.
- Miller participated in the filming of Reds in the late 1970s.
- Miller held an ongoing correspondence of over 1,500 letters with Brenda Venus between 1978 and 1981.
- Miller died on June 7, 1980 at his home in Pacific Palisades, Los Angeles, aged 88.
- The Henry Miller Memorial Library was founded in Big Sur in 1981 by Emil White.

final_events.early:
- Henry Valentine Miller was born in New York City on December 26, 1891.
- He lived at 450 East 85th Street in Manhattan during his early years.
- His family moved to Williamsburg, Brooklyn when he was around nine years old, and later to Bushwick.
- Miller attended Eastern District High School in Williamsburg.
- He briefly studied at the City College of New York.
- Miller became active with the Socialist Party of America.
- He admired Hubert Harrison.
- He was brought up in Brooklyn.
final_events.personal:
- Miller married Beatrice Sylvas Wickens in 1917 and divorced her in 1923. They had a daughter, Barbara.
- Miller met June Mansfield around 1924 and they married on June 1, 1924.
- Miller left his job with Western Union in New York to devote himself to writing in 1924.
- Miller lived with Kronski at some point between 1926-1927.
- In 1930, Miller moved to Paris and visited Greece in 1939. During his ten-year stay in France, he became fluent in French.
- Miller toured the United States extensively between 1940-41 before settling in Big Sur, California.
- Miller returned to New York in 1940 and moved to California in 1942, initially residing just outside Hollywood in Beverly Glen before settling in Big Sur in 1944.
- Miller married Janina Martha Lepska in 1944 and had two children with her. They divorced in 1952.
- Miller married Eve McClure in 1953 but they divorced in 1960.
- Miller married Hiroko Tokuda in 1967 but they divorced in 1977.
final_events.career:
- Miller quit Western Union to dedicate himself to writing in 1924.
- He was supported financially by Roland Freedman who paid June Mansfield to write a novel, pretending it was her work and reviewing Miller's writing weekly.
- Miller moved to Paris unaccompanied in 1930.
- He was employed as a proofreader for the Chicago Tribune Paris edition in 1931 thanks to Alfred Perlès.
- This period marked a creative time for Miller, and he began building a network of authors around Villa Seurat.
- Lawrence Durrell became a lifelong friend.
- Anaïs Nin and Hugh Guiler financially supported Miller between 1931-1934, covering his living expenses including rent at 18 Villa Seurat.
- Nin became his lover and financed the first printing of Tropic of Cancer in 1934 with money from Otto Rank.
- Miller's career as a writer began when he left his job at Western Union to focus on writing full-time in 1924.
- He spent significant time abroad for his work, first in France (1930), later Greece (1939).
- His travels also included an extensive tour of the United States between 1940-41.
final_events.legacy:
- Miller was nominated for the Nobel Prize in Literature by University of Copenhagen professor Allan Philip in 1973.
- Miller participated in the filming of Reds in the late 1970s.
- Miller held an ongoing correspondence of over 1,500 letters with Brenda Venus between 1978 and 1981.
- Miller died on June 7, 1980 at his home in Pacific Palisades, Los Angeles, aged 88. He is remembered for his significant contributions to literature and his influence on other authors.
- The Henry Miller Memorial Library was founded in Big Sur in 1981 by Emil White.

raw_extracted_events:
Here's a consolidated and chronological list of biographical events for Henry Miller, based on the provided text:

*   **December 26, 1891:** Henry Miller was born in New York City.
*   **Childhood:** Miller was brought up in Brooklyn.
*   **1924:** Miller left his job with Western Union in New York to devote himself to writing.
*   **1930:** Miller went to France.
*   **1939:** Miller visited Greece.
*   **1940–41:** Miller toured the United States extensively.
*   **Later Years:** Miller settled in Big Sur, California, becoming the center of a colony of admirers.
*   **June 7, 1980:** Henry Miller died in Pacific Palisades, California, at the age of 88.
